Award.AwardTitle: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track B Creating an Integrated Emergency and Crisis Response System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The 911 system remains the primary way in which Americans seek help when facing a crisis. However, the multiple public agencies that field 911 calls remain disconnected and dependent upon the judgment of the person answering the call, with some individuals “self-resolving” emergencies out of a distrust of authorities. This has led to a national conversation about how local government can better address crisis situations and avoid tragic outcomes. This project will bring together multiple entities responsible for the 911 network, including Hennepin County, the Hennepin County Sheriff’s Office, and the City of Minneapolis. Together and in conjunction with existing efforts, this project will work to develop an organizationally unified and technologically integrated emergency response that makes it easier for the public to identify who to call for help and for the appropriate personnel to be dispatched to the scene, depending on the situation. The project team will examine technology tools, like Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, to help responders assess an emergency situation and route it to the right professionals.<br/><br/>The goal is to create a nationally replicable model that integrates technology and emergency response systems to respond more appropriately to the diversity of crises that people face. The project team will seek community input regarding the types of resources and diversity of situations that require emergency response and will work with the community partners to define standards around responses and what professionals are required for each. The Stage I grant will assess the current emergency and crisis response landscape, map its diverse parts and their level of connection, work with city and county staff members to discuss what a more adaptable system might look like, and engage community members to gather their insights in order to build trust and improve upon mental health emergency response that effectively meets their diverse needs while minimizing cost and optimizing resource deployment. The planning phase will take 4 months, during which the team will develop a pilot project for implementation and testing in a 12-month Stage II grant. Technically, the team will examine existing AI applications for their applicability to emergency response in cities. We will also develop AI and Machine-Learning technology that leverages the knowledge and experience of emergency responders. The team will look, as well, at sharing-economy strategies to explore the use of often-overlooked community assets in responding to emergencies to ensure that people have access to the services they need.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 911 system remains the primary way by which people seek emergency help. Yet the 911 system:

●      Deploys emergency personnel who may or may not be the appropriate professionals, depending upon the nature of the emergency

●      Uses a unidirectional call-based system that does not account for the myriad communications channels that people currently use

●      Has difficulty locating with high precision the approximately 80% of callers who use cell phones, making rapid response more difficult

●      Relies on dispatchers who must make quick decisions with limited information under stressful conditions, resulting in high turnover

●      Lacks a standard underlying technology in the 6,100 Public Safety Answering Points (PSAPs) in the US, resulting in widely varying capabilities

Overall, the 911 system reflects an older way of organizing systems.

●      It is a centralized system, with a hub-and-spoke structure where calls come into a central PSAP on a limited number of lines that can be overloaded during emergencies.

●      It is a closed system, with communication between dispatchers and responders using walkie-talkie-based radio communications with poor sound quality.

●      It is antiquated system, that is highly dependent upon land-based phone lines even though 80+% of calls come from cell phones, whose locations are difficult to pinpoint.

●      It is a fragmented system, with multiple PSAP?s operating independently, with a range of technical and personnel capabilities.

●      It is a fracture-critical system, with both the dispatcher and responder operating in high- stress situations, where miscommunication could delay an effective response or produce the wrong response to the caller?s needs.

The U.S. needs a more resilient, flexible, and adaptive emergency response system, better able to identify the specifics of an emergency and to allow for effective triage and deployment of the most appropriate response. We also need a more unified and technologically integrated emergency response system that makes it easier for dispatchers in PSAPs to understand what the most appropriate response might be, using augmented intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies.

Our research team from the University of Minnesota and Hennepin County surveyed the literature on this topic, interviewed diverse staff members responsible for various aspects of emergency response, and coordinated our work with the county?s 911 Mental Health Task Force. We also looked at the technology and software currently being used or potentially available to improve the 911 system.

There are many products and technologies that help identify a caller?s location, but there is almost no technology that helps emergency responders understand why a call has been made, beyond what the caller says. With ML-based AI technology, dispatchers and responders can have a better idea, based on historical data and nuanced natural-language understanding, of the caller?s needs and what the most appropriate emergency response might be.

For AI and ML to correctly identify needs and the best action to take in response, it needs to include:

●      Natural Language Processing (NLP): Converting the speech into text.

●      Natural Language Understanding (NLU): Adding meaning to what is being said and assessing the tenor, emotion, and magnitude of the caller?s voice.

●      Realtime and Historical Identification of the reasons for a 911 call.

●      Routing non-emergency calls to the appropriate endpoint to handle the situation, managed through a public switched telephone network (PSTN)

In addition to the AI-based model to identify why a caller is looking for emergency services, there is also the need to answer calls during large scale events that overload the capacity of PSAPs. Non-emergency calls could be managed in the PSTN, with certain providers allowing for bursting of calls that can identify the acknowledgement of the event and allow for callers who need help outside of the event to still get through to a dispatcher.

With the AI system?s natural language understanding, dispatchers will have an aid that could ultimately help them determine the most appropriate service response to match the need of the caller (e.g., police, social worker, mental health worker, drug counselor, etc.), informed by a jurisdiction?s evolving approach to alternative responses. The AI system, if detecting that an immediate response is not warranted, could help dispatchers route callers to a different channel such as a 311 line or other non-emergency helplines.

Research has shown that adding other call lines to reroute 911 calls does not make the call-taker job more efficient. Identifying calls that do not warrant an immediate response more quickly will ensure that calls, even if non-emergency, receive the most appropriate response and are directed to the most appropriate resource. The goal is not to replace dispatchers or determine what they should do, but instead to augment their decisions with more information and recommendations based on prior experience, while reducing the stress placed on dispatchers, which leads to a high turnover rate of personnel.
